question: Question_05
statement:
In the 1986 Chernobyl reactor explosion, substantial amounts of the
isotope strontium-90 (\textsuperscript{90}Sr) contaminated the area
around the nuclear plant. \textsuperscript{90}Sr undergoes exponential
radioactive decay with a half-life of 29 years. Write down a
``calculator-ready`` expression for the percentage of the origina
\textsuperscript{90}Sr remaining today (use the year the exam was
written).
sols:
We know that the amount of \textsuperscript{90}Sr remaining at a time
$t$ is modeled by the equation $S(t) = S_0e^{kt}$, where $S_0$ is the
initial quantity and \emph{k} is a rate of decay. Our first task is to
find \emph{k}. Using the information that the half-life of
\textsuperscript{90}Sr is 29 years, we know that when \emph{t} = 29,
\emph{S}(29) = \emph{S}\textsubscript{0}/2. Plugging this into our
equation of exponential decay, we get:

\begin{align*}
S_0 e^{k\cdot29} &= \frac{S_0}2  \\
e^{k\cdot29} &= \frac12 \\
k\cdot29  &= \ln\left(\frac12\right) \\
k &= \frac{\ln\left(\frac12\right)}{29}
\end{align*}

Note that \emph{k} \textless{} 0 as expected: the amount of
\textsuperscript{90}Sr declines over time. Putting \emph{k} back into
the formula $S(t) = S_0e^{kt}$, we get

\[\displaystyle
S(t) = S_0e^{(\ln(1/2)/29) t}\]

You can leave this expression as is, or simplify it to get

\[\displaystyle
S(t) = S_0\left(1/2\right)^{t/29}\]

To find the percentage of \textsuperscript{90}Sr remaining today, we
simply plug in the amount of time that has elapsed since the initial
explosion in 1986; in 2011, that is 25 years. So

\[\displaystyle
S(25) = S_0(1/2)^{25/29}\]

The percentage of $S_0$ remaining is thus

\[\frac{S(25)}{S(0)} = \frac{S_0(1/2)^{25/29}}{S_0} = (1/2)^{25/29}\]
hints:
The formula for exponential radioactive decay is $S(t) = S_0e^{kt}$,
where \emph{S}\textsubscript{0} is the initial quantity and \emph{k} is
a rate of decay. How can you use the information about the half-life of
\textsuperscript{90}Sr to find \emph{k}?
